questions.question_text: Which of the following are matter? Chair, air, love, smell, hate, almonds, thought, cold, cold drink, smell of perfume.
hints: Recall definition of matter: anything that has mass and occupies space.
Think about physical existence vs. emotions/ideas.

questions.question_text: Give reasons for the following observation: The smell of hot sizzling food reaches you several metres away, but to get the smell from cold food you have to go close.
hints: Consider kinetic energy of particles in hot vs. cold substances.
Relate to diffusion rate and temperature.

questions.question_text: A diver is able to cut through water in a swimming pool. Which property of matter does this observation show?
hints: Think about intermolecular forces and space between particles in liquids.
Relate to fluidity.

questions.question_text: What are the characteristics of the particles of matter?
hints: List properties like space between particles, attraction, motion.
Recall kinetic theory.

questions.question_text: The mass per unit volume of a substance is called density. (Density = mass/volume). Arrange the following in order of increasing density – air, exhaust from chimney, honey, water, chalk, cotton and iron.
hints: Compare densities of common substances.
Remember gases have very low density, solids high.

questions.question_text: a) Tabulate the differences in the characteristics of states of matter. b) Comment upon the following: rigidity, compressibility, fluidity, filling a gas container, shape, kinetic energy and density.
hints: Create a table comparing solid, liquid, gas.
Define each term in context of states.

questions.question_text: Give reasons: a) A gas fills completely the vessel in which it is kept. b) A gas exerts pressure on the walls of the container. c) A wooden table should be called a solid. d) We can easily move our hand in air but to do the same through a solid block of wood we need a karate expert.
hints: Use kinetic theory: particles move randomly, collide with walls.
Consider intermolecular forces and spaces.

questions.question_text: Liquids generally have lower density as compared to solids. But you must have observed that ice floats on water. Find out why.
hints: Recall anomalous expansion of water.
Think about structure of ice vs. liquid water.

questions.question_text: Convert the following temperatures to the Celsius scale: a) 300 K b) 573 K.
hints: Use formula: °C = K - 273.

questions.question_text: Convert the following temperatures to the Kelvin scale: a) 25°C b) 373°C.
hints: Use formula: K = °C + 273.

questions.question_text: Give reason for the following observations: a) Naphthalene balls disappear with time without leaving any solid. b) We can get the smell of perfume sitting several metres away.
hints: Think about sublimation and diffusion.
Relate to particle motion and vaporization.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following substances in increasing order of forces of attraction between the particles – water, sugar, oxygen.
hints: Compare forces in solid, liquid, gas.
Sugar (solid) > water (liquid) > oxygen (gas).

questions.question_text: What is the physical state of water at: a) 25°C b) 0°C c) 100°C?
hints: Recall melting and boiling points of water.
Consider state at given temperatures.

questions.question_text: Give two reasons to justify: a) Water at room temperature is a liquid. b) An iron almirah is a solid at room temperature.
hints: Use properties of liquids and solids.
Consider intermolecular forces and rigidity.

questions.question_text: Why is ice at 273 K more effective in cooling than water at the same temperature?
hints: Consider latent heat of fusion.
Energy absorbed during melting provides extra cooling.

questions.question_text: What produces more severe burns, boiling water or steam?
hints: Recall latent heat of vaporization.
Steam has extra energy compared to boiling water.

questions.question_text: Name A, B, C, D, E and F in the following diagram showing change in state:
hints: Identify processes: melting, vaporization, condensation, freezing, sublimation, deposition.
